<displayTitle>A dirge for Wellington ; By Martin F. Tupper</displayTitle>

DIRGE. I A voice of lamentation From the islands of the Sea! Alas, thou sorrowing Nation Bereav'd,âAlas for Thee! The wail as of a mother Weeping for her son,â When shall she bear another Like that illustrious One? II O Britain, broken-hearted, Bemoan the bitter day,â Thy Hero is departed, Thy Glory rent away,â Alas! our joys are made to cease, Our praise of old is fled, Though first in war, and first in peace,â Our Wellington is dead! III Was he not both our torch of war, And learning's peaceful lamp, Achilles in the battle-jar, And Nestor in the camp?â Our light is from us taken To shine in other skies, And we are left, forsaken Of the valiant and the wise! IV How are the mighty scattered That have lost their iron lord! The shield and spear are shattered, The battle and the sword! The Champion of all Europe's rights Is gone to his long rest,â The Hero of a hundred fights With endless Peace is blest! V Arise, angelic keepers That watch the waiting dead; And turn, ye silent sleepers, Upon your narrow bed! Arise,âand to those shadowy bands Make this great spirit known, The Guardian mind of many lands, The Saviour of his own! VI Mournfully, with measured pace The sad procession brings Our chieftain to the resting place Of heroes and of kings; And mournfully the minute gun Tolls out to earth and air The groans of Britain, one by one, The sobs of her despair. VII Step by step, with pomp and plume And black funereal state, In solemn progress to the tomb They reach the sacred gate; Ye trumpets, hold your bated breath, Be still, ye muffled drums, For to the hallowed halls of Death The conquering hero comes! VIII Yea! conquering still:âtheir leaden prison (Through HIM who died to save) The dead shall burst, redeem'd and risen Triumphant o'er the grave: The dead,âyea, this our Chief; though not By mortal might nor power But by GOD'S Spirit, in his lot Shall stand at that dread hour. IX Meekly with charitable gaze His faults or foibles scan,â For he might walk this earthly maze Not more, nor less, than man; Doubtless, he owned to sins and wrongs Like all beside that live,â Yet, unto us his good belongs, His illâmay GOD forgive! X But stoutly too, with glad acclaim Tell out his honest worth,â There never lived a child of fame More childlike on this earth! Simple in heart, sincere in mind, Just, resolute, and true, Duty was all he strove to find, And all he dared to do! XI Duty, though Death were on the track, Though scorn were in the way, Duty, though pleasure beckoned back, Or interest lured astray; Duty, Great Chief! thy glorious name Is link'd with Duty still, Through civic strife, and martial fame Through good report and ill! XII O, who shall worthily record The trophies of his fame, The wisdom of his lightest word, The weight of his great name? For kings and men of every clime Right nobly vied to raise His glory's monument sublime With pinnacles of praise! XIII Remember him, thou City Of perjured Sahib slain, How prompt his heart to pity, How glad to heal again; Remember well his lightning eye, False Scindiah, in that day When myriads could not fight nor fly The Victor of Assaye! XIV Sad Lusitania! lost and won In adverse fortune's night, Remember him, whose presence shone Thine Arbiter of Right; Remember him, thy conquering Chief In red Vimiera's day,â His gauntlet wiped thy tears of grief, And swept thy foes away! XV O rescued Spain, consider still His glorious deeds for thee,â The wonders of his forceful skill That saved and set thee free! Barrossa! Talavera! Vittoria!âfated name,â And scores beside sound far and wide The echoes of his fame. XVI Of Fabian caution, lingering well Before the leaguered fosse, Let ridgy Torres Vedras tell And storm-won Badajoz: Of Julian vigour, swift to wreak Full vengeance on the Gaul, In thunder, San Sebastian, speak To Cuidad's echoing wall! XVII O thwarted France, in thy worst hour The scourge and curse of Man,â O fell incarnate lust of power, Thou baffled Corsican,â Yell out his praise, whose trophied life Was crown'd by crushing you, And sear'd your hydra-heads of strife In branding Waterloo! XVIII Weep, grateful Prussia well allied, And thou, black Brunswick, weep! And, Austria, swell this tribute tide Of sorrow loud and deep: All nations well avenged in fight, All kingdoms of the world, Mourn him, who still to help the Right His battle flag unfurl'd. XIX Bewail, O land, thy patriot true The bulwark of thy state; Clear to expound, and bold to do, In all things he was Great: Bewail, ye cliffs, that white and hoar By castled Dover stand,â Alas! that ye shall see no more Our Nelson of the Land! XX Ah, bitter day! I hear a groan From Britain's heart of oak; Forth from the altar and the throne That voice of anguish broke: Alas, that he should perish From the face of this dull earth, And leave us but to cherish The remembrance of his worth! XXI Full of honours, full of years, Our Chief is dead and gone! His epitaph a nation's tears As for a first-born son: Though dead and gone,âyet shall he live! Yea, live for earth, and heaven,â By all that Man to Mind can give, Or GOD to Soul hath given! XXII He lives, by trophies of the sword, By triumphs of the pen,â He lives, by noble deed and word Within the hearts of men: He is not dead, but sleepeth,â Then why should Britain go As one that sorely weepeth Uncomforted in woe? XXIII With every earthly honour won, And every praise achieved, With every human duty done His crown of light is weaved: On Heaven's own archives, man may trust, Not less than history's page, His high reward isâWith the Just To live in every age!
